Award.AwardTitle: The International Criminal Court and the Pursuit of Justice

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Maxine Kamari Clarke of Yale University will conduct research on international justice and human rights as these concepts have been interpreted by the International Criminal Court and the African Union Commission. The past two years have witnessed the ICC's intensive focus on African states, including arrest warrants for numerous African leaders. The proposed research -- shaped by current theoretical debates on the globalization of human rights, the anthropology of justice, and genealogies of affect -- explores contestations over justice, documenting the making of the Rome Statute for the ICC and the corresponding rise of the rule of law movement.

The project will take place at two critical sites: (1) the ICC at The Hague, in which investigations and adjudication are ongoing; (2) the AU Commission in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, where political, economic and culturally shaped decision-making is underway toward the development of an African court with the jurisdiction to handle international crimes committed by individuals. Data will be collected at each site through a variety of social science methods, including interviews, participant observation, and archival research, and analyzed to test three major hypotheses concerning (1) the globalization of human rights and the cooperation of AU leaders; (2) the factors affecting the nature and form of struggles over the meanings of justice; (3) the structures of affect that shape AU cooperation with the ICC.

As international justice mechanisms continue to evolve, there is a special urgency to this research as it relates to appropriate forms of legal involvement in the pursuit of peace. This project will advance scientific understandings of international law and justice in the field of Law and Social Sciences, especially in anthropology or interdisciplinary studies of law. The research will also contribute to the training of a graduate student. The empirical findings of this study will be of great importance to policymakers, providing insights into the motivating factors, experiences, and concerns of international justice mechanisms. This research was co-funded by the Cultural Anthropology program and the Law and Social Sciences program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the major goals of this project was to understand why African national leaders and their stakeholders are defying calls for international justice by the International Criminal Court and what this can tell us about better ways to manage violent conflict in Sub-Saharan Africa. This inter-disciplinary project merges anthropology, law, social theory and legal theory, as well as social science methods.  This research projects explores the current tensions between international criminal justice and African regional bodies and seeks to understand contestations between various leaders of African states, survivors of violence, human rights stakeholders and the current pursuit of those bodies to prosecute African leaders. This project—shaped by current theoretical debates concerning the globalization of human rights, the anthropology of justice, and genealogies of affect—explores contestations over appropriate judicial practices in The Hague and in various regions of sub-Saharan Africa. As an interdisciplinary project, it analyzes the desires, fears, concerns, and histories of Africa encounter with and subordination to international law.

 

During the three-year project, the PI and her research team conducted ethnographic research in several cities on three continents including Arusha, Addis Ababa, Nairobi, The Hague, Kano and Miami.  The PI worked with scholars, lawyers, diplomats, advisors, and civil-society groups to collect data, assess negotiation documents, engage with and study the adoption of strategies, and do ongoing advisory work. The research team also worked with civil society organizations such as Coalition for the International Criminal Court, Amnesty International and the Open Society Justice Initiative.  In addition, the PI attended the 20th and 21st African Union Summit Meetings, as well as the annual Assembly of States Parties (ASP) of the ICC in The Hague. By the end of the project, the PI and her team had conducted over 180 interviews and spent three years working at the heart of ICC and Africa issues.

 

Another major and very significant activity during this period was the PI becoming part of an advisory team involved in the work of a new African court tasked with contemplating and assessing the new judicial architecture. The PI and her research team established a formal affiliation with the Pan-African Lawyer’s Union and the Open Society Initiative West Africa, with which they worked as partners to shape the future of justice institutions in Africa and beyond. Some of this work was based in cities such as Arusha, The Hague, New York City, Miami, and Toronto, as well as in various consultancy and advisory settings in Addis Ababa. It involved working with scholars, lawyers, diplomats, advisors, and civil-society groups to procure research data, assess negotiation documents, engage with and study the adoption of strategies, and conduct ongoing advisory work.  The ongoing goal is the creation of a network of scholars specializing in issues that can contribute to the eradication of violence.

 

This project explored the proliferation and management of conflict globally. The results of the study demonstrate that once promising solutions have challenged extant social and political notions about how to prevent large-scale violence. Social scientists have a critically important role to play in understanding how interventions are adapted or contested, thereby amplifying the varied voices of directly impacted stakeholders. They can contribute to the management of violence by exploring the way that justice is mediated through history, power, and cultural meanings. This research highlights the importance of deconstructing and historicizing contemporary concepts whose meanings have effects that we are only just beginning to understand.
